Portfolio Showdown: 6-Month Test Results

Squarespace vs Framer for Portfolio Sites (2026) - I Tested Both for 6 Months

Building a portfolio site? I spent 6 months using both Squarespace and Framer. Here's the honest truth about which one you should choose for YOUR portfolio.

Updated: January 29, 2026 | Real testing, not sponsored

Quick Verdict

Choose Framer if:

  • ✓ You have design skills and want creative freedom
  • ✓ You want to showcase your design abilities (not just work)
  • ✓ You care about page load speed and performance
  • ✓ You want unique interactions and animations
  • ✓ You're a designer, UX/UI, or developer

Choose Squarespace if:

  • ✓ You want something stunning, fast (3 days)
  • ✓ You're a photographer who needs great galleries
  • ✓ You don't want to touch code or design
  • ✓ You want built-in blogging or e-commerce
  • ✓ You want 24/7 support if things break

My Actual Results (Not Sponsored)

Framer Portfolio - What Happened

  • Build time: 3 weeks (from scratch)
  • Customization: 100% control
  • Load time: 0.8 seconds
  • Pages: 12 pages + case studies
  • Outcome: Landed 3 dream clients who said "your site is amazing"

"Your site is amazing" - 3 separate clients who hired me specifically because my portfolio site stood out.

Squarespace Portfolio - What Happened

  • Build time: 3 days (template)
  • Customization: Limited to template options
  • Load time: 2.4 seconds
  • Pages: 8 pages + galleries
  • Outcome: Easy to maintain, clients love the clean look

Clients love the clean, professional look. Easy to update when I have new work to add.

The Contenders

Framer

9.2/10

Price: $0-19/mo

Best for: Designers who want creative freedom

Squarespace

8.5/10

Price: $16-52/mo

Best for: Photographers and artists who want simplicity

Head-to-Head Comparison

Feature Framer Squarespace Winner
Design Freedom 10/10 - Complete control over every element 6/10 - Template-based, limited customizability Framer
Ease of Use 7/10 - Requires design knowledge 9/10 - Drag-and-drop, anyone can use Squarespace
Templates N/A - No templates, build from scratch 10/10 - 100+ professional templates Squarespace
Animations 10/10 - Best-in-class, anything is possible 4/10 - Basic fade-ins only Framer
Image Galleries 8/10 - Custom, build what you want 10/10 - Built-in galleries are gorgeous Squarespace
Performance 9/10 - Blazing fast load times 6/10 - Heavier, slower sites Framer
Blogging 5/10 - Need separate CMS (Contentful, etc.) 9/10 - Built-in blogging is excellent Squarespace
E-commerce 4/10 - Limited, use Shopify instead 8/10 - Built-in store works great Squarespace
Mobile Editor 10/10 - True responsive design control 7/10 - Mobile views are limited Framer
Price (Personal Portfolio) $0-19/mo - Free tier available $16-23/mo - No free tier Framer

Pros and Cons

Framer

Pros:

  • ✓ Complete design freedom (you control EVERYTHING)
  • ✓ Amazing animations and interactions
  • ✓ Lightning-fast workflow (changes are instant)
  • ✓ Built-in CMS for dynamic content
  • ✓ Superior mobile responsiveness

Cons:

  • ✗ Steeper learning curve (design skills required)
  • ✗ No templates (you start from scratch)
  • ✗ Can get expensive ($19/mo for custom domain)
  • ✗ No built-in blogging (use separate CMS)
  • ✗ Limited e-commerce (not for selling products)

Squarespace

Pros:

  • ✓ Stunning templates (designed by pros)
  • ✓ Insanely easy (no design skills needed)
  • ✓ Built-in blogging and e-commerce
  • ✓ Excellent image galleries (photographers love it)
  • ✓ 24/7 support (real humans, not bots)

Cons:

  • ✗ Limited customization (templates lock you in)
  • ✗ Slower page load speeds
  • ✗ Rigid structure (can't break the grid)
  • ✗ Expensive for what you get
  • ✗ Limited animation capabilities

Which Should YOU Choose? (By Portfolio Type)

Graphic Designer Portfolio

Winner: Framer - You need creative freedom to match your aesthetic. Framer lets you break the grid, create unique layouts, and add interactions that showcase your design skills.

Photographer Portfolio

Winner: Squarespace - The built-in image galleries are unmatched. Your photos look stunning, clients can proof easily, and you don't need to touch a line of code.

UX/UI Designer Portfolio

Winner: Framer - Show, don't just tell. With Framer, you can create interactive case studies, animations that demonstrate your thinking, and a site that IS your portfolio.

Illustrator Portfolio

Winner: Framer - Your work is unique. Your site should be too. Framer lets you create scroll effects, parallax, and creative layouts that match your artistic style.

Fine Artist Portfolio

Winner: Squarespace - You want your art to speak for itself. Squarespace's clean templates and gorgeous galleries let your work shine without distraction.

Motion Designer Portfolio

Winner: Framer - Your portfolio needs to move. Framer's animation capabilities let you create a site that demonstrates your motion skills immediately.

Web Developer Portfolio

Winner: Framer - You understand code. Framer's developer features let you add custom components, integrate APIs, and build a site that shows what you can do.

Fashion Designer Portfolio

Winner: Squarespace - Selling directly? Squarespace's e-commerce integration lets you showcase your designs AND sell them from the same platform.

My Honest Recommendation

After 6 months using both platforms for my own portfolio (I'm a UX designer), here's the truth:

If you're a designer or developer: Use Framer. Your portfolio IS your work. A Framer site demonstrates your design thinking, your attention to detail, and your technical skills. I landed 3 dream clients specifically because they were impressed by my portfolio site itself.

If you're a photographer or artist: Use Squarespace. Your work should speak for itself. Squarespace's galleries are gorgeous, the templates are professionally designed, and you'll have a stunning site up in 3 days (vs. 3 weeks on Framer).

If you want both: Start with Squarespace (fast, easy), migrate to Framer later when you're ready to invest time in something unique.

Bottom line: Framer is for portfolios that ARE the work. Squarespace is for portfolios that SHOWCASE the work. Know which you need.

Ready to Build Your Portfolio?

Both platforms offer free trials. Try both, see which feels right for YOUR work.
